text: so we have about 45 minutes to talk about procurements and they always seem
to put day and it's always one of these topics that doesn't really grab however in a
cloud environment this is critical the how you buy cloud has become probably
one of the biggest issues for governments adopting how how they use and use effectively cloud so what we're
gonna do is we're gonna talk about some of the general pieces of how cloud procurement works and then we're gonna
have Henry Pinto come up Henry is from Honduras he's actually done this from the government side he's
actually done a procurement gone through the process learned some of the same lessons that we've seen he's going to
talk about his experience he'll do it in Spanish and then we'll come back and we'll talk about some of the best
practices okay okay so so I already
talked about that so introduction so the biggest thing I get to do my job takes me around the world I get to work with
governments in Europe in Asia and here in South America and it's amazing to me
what people say everybody says we're different and the reality at the core how government buys and does procurement
is actually very similar around the world it's the same type of thinking the same kind of things my job and my team's
job and really the broader organization's job is to help governments by cloud effectively and
procurement tends to get in the way of that traditional procurement and so we're here to help with a in a sense a
cultural shift out of a traditional hardware or software buying approach to
an approach that allows you to effectively use cloud and that's a big shift that is a cultural shift and it
affects a number of different parts of government it affects obviously the technology folks it affects how the business folks
work procurement legal contracts and finance are all involved in this and so
you know one thing to think about is this we go forward on this is how do you bring in those teams to drive those
pieces for because they all have a say in it and in the end you end up with some governance we've got a couple of governments we can talk about where
they've actually reached a point where they can buy cloud reasonably effectively and they're starting to really use it to transform how they use
technology within their government and that's where we want to get you to okay so look at
the English one so so what why is cloud different it's it's it's um you know
there's an initial reaction that I am I'm buying more hardware or buying more software and really what you're buying
is you're you're buying access to a set of services a set of building blocks online and you're moving away from the
traditional approach so we have to get out of the the thinking of physical resources or get out of the the idea of
I'm building a specific set of solutions and I need a specific set of products to do that you want to have access to all
of those services so understanding this difference is critical so you know we're
working right now with governments including in Columbia to work through this this this difference and why it is
different the the analogy I use is and I'm I'll see if I remember right it's
here in Columbia it's home center in the US with the Home Depot maybe the equivalent and what it is is is if you
think about it that way you're coming in to access a set of services you go to a home center to to buy a set of things to
accomplish something we are these building blocks and that's what we provide at an AWS level and you go out
and you try to find those and you work either yourself to build something or you hire maybe a contractor from a home
center perspective or a partner of AWS to help you build out a solution using
the AWS tools that is very different than buying from a system integrator in the traditional way where they build
everything so that is part of the cultural shift that we have to do so I
think probably everybody's seen this throughout the day sort of understanding our model and very quickly you know
twenty regions around the world twelve more of 65 AZ's huge infrastructure we
have 160 plus services I think at this point I can't even keep track anymore and but recognize what this is from
return respective this is the same set of services running in all of these places forever
single customer these are not uniquely built resources these aren't specifically built for a specific
customer these are all these building blocks are there for everybody to use so
anybody can log on and anybody can open an account and use this and use these services anywhere in the world so
thinking about this in a traditional data center approach is something we have to shift away from so where are we
today with procurements how many people in this room are with government or with government procurement can say I see a
couple of hands so government procurement right now is is it there's
there's been a way of buying technology that's been around for probably 30 or 40 years that people are used to buying a
certain way buying hardware buying software or using a system integration approach to buy a solution and so
typically these approaches are they take a long time I've been through more
procurements that have taken 2 or 3 years they are very prescriptive here's exactly what I want
minimal flexibility typically they use traditional terms and conditions and
we'll talk about those traditional security approaches this is the way we've done security this is the way
we're going to continue to do security fixed pricing so all of these areas are
sort of traditional ways of doing things and this is part of what we have to shift out of is this approach so how do
you get to wide adoption of the cloud so first is understanding what the cloud
is I was just talking to a government today and I said have you actually used it
have you actually got on hands on keyboard or has somebody in your team do it no we haven't done that yet
and I can't tell you more you have to understand the business model of how the cloud works I'll never forget talking to
a lawyer in Brazil and back and forth arguing over this issue and we said
let's look at the console and let's go in there and do it and it was an aha moment when we did it and so first just
understand how the cloud works and it's really important to do that as you go forward second is understanding the
policies around how you operate and often there are policies around security or pricing or
data sovereignty those kinds of things that are they policies maybe they are
maybe they aren't maybe they're just sort of tradition how you do things or or is it a policy that can be shifted so
understand how traditional policies work with with with policies are on the cloud and that's an ongoing discussion that
we're already having here in Columbia and elsewhere in the world understanding the security model and we'll talk a
little bit about the security model as we go forward pretermit and that's what we're here to talk about today and
that's a big chunk of this is understanding the buying process and finally there's a cultural shift here
and I talked about that in the beginning is there's a series of different groups within the government that have to think
about how they they they shift their way of doing things that's not easy it's a hard it can be a difficult thing to do
it is a journey and we're happy us and our partners to help work through that but ultimately these are the steps that
we've seen to get folks to wide adoption and we've got some countries I was talking to earlier today about Singapore
Singapore has been through several steps of this and they built out a framework and sort of worked they have finally
just gone to a whole-of-government agreement with a number of CSPs including us and we're gonna buy it and
use it how you guys do it is what they finally got to it was a journey to get there so we recognize that journey we're
here to help you with that journey so a couple things to understand too there is
a conversation we have quite regularly about is and then pass and then SAS and where do we slot these things and all
these we have to fit these categories in these lots and I was actually talking
earlier today about this is I've been here at Amazon for six years and if you asked me to post put all my products
into I ass and pass I would struggle with that even today and the question is doesn't really matter now understanding
that you need to access these services so understand that there's some differences with them but at the same time you want to have access to all of
them through one thing breaking them up into pieces makes things more difficult on top of that another aspect of this
too with these three areas is terms and conditions and making sure you understand how those terms and
conditions work between the three not to have a blanket set to another area to go into but I understand

so back to English so we're gonna talk about we're gonna talk about a couple or
five kind of core things we see about cloud this is not everything but it's a
few things that are core around procurement and what you have to think about procurement and so these are some
very high-level sort of discussion points obviously there's deeper material out there and we can talk about that as
well so first we talked about performance-based requirements what we
run into is we've talked about going back to the traditional approach and we
just actually ran into an RFP in another country today that the the the CIO is
office very excited about doing this working with cloud took these ideas and
brought it into their procurement shop there was never discussion between the three or a cloud provider like Amazon it
just went into the into the black hole of procurement and what they did is they created using their traditional
approaches a very prescriptive a very traditional procurement approach and so
now we have a document that is going to be very difficult to use cloud effectively so what we want to what we
have to shift away from is that very specific list of things and understand the broader use of cloud and how you
build solutions with these building blocks we want to have those building blocks on all of them available we don't
want to have to sit down and prescribe them an example that we run into is creating a list here are the services we
want fit your services into them and trying to fit our services into a set of
prescribed requirements is actually impossible if you go back to the
original not impossible but very difficult if you go back to that list of all those regions that we have and all
those services that we have us trying to fit our services and change them for
each individual contract is something that doesn't work with the mom so we want to we want to make sure we're
focused not on the details of the line items and the requirements it's actually what is the performance that I want to
get and a good cloud procurement a good cloud framework a good cloud contract works around how you what you're ending
up with how well can I build a website how fast and how effective can it be how can I build a database do I have the
right types of databases to do this well they run effectively is the high availability there how do I bring these
pieces together and can I grow them and shrink them as I need to it's focusing on the performance and building a
contract to do the performance and allow the performance to be used so you know a
few other things on the bottom there we talked about some of the and we'll talk about some of the certifications but bringing in sort of traditional
approaches around certifications and how how a data center should operate and
I'll give you an example there's no other country in the world that brought in datacenter specifications and one of
the specifications was the thickness of the door the thickness of the door and
somehow somehow we know this but our doors were a couple of millimeters short
of their thickness requirement and so that is an incredibly prescriptive requirement that has absolutely no
bearing on how well you're going to operate on this and so these are the kind of things to think about is to understand that allow these cloud
providers to understand how they work and understand the security and all the pieces that are there but allow them to
be what they are so over-prescription is is one of the first areas that you want to understand as you're going forward on this this
this journey so another area is around pretermit and how you buy the initial
the initial approach we talked about the home center analogy earlier the initial
approach is always I want to go direct I want to buy AWS we are happy to do that but we want to make sure that by an
agency's procurement or other understand what's necessary in this first you can
buy from us directly but there are other options that are out there for you can there are other you need the service
providers to help you with that contracting piece like we talked about or you can buy access to AWS
through one of our partners as well so understanding that broader approach to
how to buy cloud and understand there are different options to do this is critically important so stepping back
and saying instead of the traditional I want a distributor model or I want this model is understanding what's there and
the best model really is having access to AWS directly using the services the
building blocks but having this pool of services of managed service providers
consultants trainers because the cloud is a big place there's a lot you can do with the cloud I feel for our solution
architects you watch their face at reinvent where we release our new services and you see them excited but
also terrified at the same time when there's 30 new services that they have to learn so under and having that
ability to keep up with that and having the services to do that is critical so the takeaway from this is having
understanding the different models that are there and finding the best model for you and working through that model so we
talked about the direct and indirect method it's a couple of areas and these are just very high-level things of approaches how to buy cloud first we've
seen countries including the United States and Europe using an existing contract they actually try to fit in
cloud into a potentially a hardware contractor not the best but it's a way
to get started it's it's an option and we've seen it actually work or it works under a services type contract or cloud
could be bought so it's an option to think about creating a mechanism to buy clouds really where we want to get to
and having a a cloud built buying mechanism now I don't use the word
framework or or RFP just whatever the buying mechanism that works that works
within the country and the government buying through a lake what I said a managed we have different types of
partners in a sense you can buy apart from a partner who will actually run
your workload for you on AWS that's great or you can buy through a partner so you can actually put your fingers on
the console and do the work yourself either one best ways they actually have both finally you can ask
cloud can be included as part of just a standard tender or RFP maybe this is one
that a system integrator is going to build a broader solution the attender can be written in a way that cloud could
be included remember the prescriptive part I talked about don't overprescribe in the in the
RFP about how that works and said say how would you do the infrastructure or how would you build the platforms and let the answer happen pricing again
pricing is an area that we we have to work through and teach and understand how the pricing works so first AWS is a
very granular set of services on purpose it gives you incredible flexibility to
use our services in the best way possible for you if you look at one of our price lists we are literally passed
20,000 line items for a region now that sounds a little daunting at first but the reality is it's incredible
flexibility to use for example like a server we call it an instance how do you use that in the exact way you want
buying the right kind using burning the right operating system for you we give that kind of flexibility you want to
allow that flexibility into the contract and we were just talking today about this again I had some interesting
conversations about contracts that are very limited they only allow in a certain set of services and there's a
downside to having only access to a little bit of a fuller set of things and so we want to help people walk work
through to have full access to that and and accept the pricing model of how the cloud works whether it's us or another
cloud provider there are these models except those commercial models rather than trying to impose a specific set of
pricing because doing that really takes away the benefits of the cloud other areas that we have to work through these
different pricing models trying to compare different cloud providers and how they work I've actually sat down and
I had some people in the room here but not on this one trying to compare prices here's line item from this one here's

allow them to come in and be what they are the other one this is what we talked about bringing the right teams in the
finance team the budget team you know pay pay pay as you go is a very different model than a we have a capex
model we're spending this much this year this is what we're spending we know it pay-as-you-go is different now
immediately we don't work that way well I've I've found with governments that if you go into their deep if you go in
deeper and you understand governments do do pay-as-you-go models cell phones electricity those kinds of things the
models are there it's all about managing it correctly and understanding the management tools that are there the governance model and that's another area
to talk about in this the shared
responsibility model this is a real critical part this cover this crosses
all of what AWS does and you know when you have a solution architect team come in they'll talk about this salesperson
will talk about this procurement talks about this this covers all of our services you have to understand it from
a procurement perspective first if you don't understand it at the bottom is AWS
we are responsible for the security of the cloud so that starts from the fences
to the data center to the access to the data center all the way up and our compute up to the hypervisor all that's
operating the compute instances above that is where the customer is working
you're working in you have this workload on there this website or this database you're responsible for the security in
the cloud so an example that would be using our Identity and Access Management and setting that up in the way that
works for you encryption using our encryption tools to encrypt the data how people on your teams can access and
utilize the cloud there's a hundred different ways our shared responsibility works so sometimes people hear that as
oh that means you're not responsible for this no we're actually giving you the responsibility you're not hoping that
your vendors taking care of this in the right way you're taking care of it in the right way and obviously we have best practices we have tools or lots of tools
built into AWS to help you manage the security so this model you have to think
about it from a procurement perspective is if you require like we've seen this
in RFPs where they require encryption the data must be encrypting well we
provide the tools to allow encryption but we don't actually encrypt it for you you can do the tools and there's a
variety of different ways to do it so it's understanding thinking around how the shared security model works into a per tournament that
you're gonna do so privacy data there's
a whole bunch of different things here around how you should take care of the privacy of it and want to make sure I

fascinating reading lately evening to read through but no there seriously when you need to understand procurement it's
worth doing the deep dive on so we talked about also how you know
accreditation works oftentimes government's want to bring in the model
they have for accrediting security and compliance and they have a model and they've used that model and I'll give
you an example this is about five years ago in forty five years ago in a country
in Asia they came in and said we have this compliance model meet it you know we said okay what's the time to meet it
and we went through it and what have we found out basically this was built on ISO 27001 with a little layer on top
that did nothing else install so we're sitting back saying why do we have to comply with this this model when we
already in a sense do it and most of time with our accreditation certifications we are already above and beyond that so understand what the cloud
provider brings to you rather than bringing your own and understand how that works with this security you're trying to achieve and that's a shift in
thinking that's bringing the security people then that we've talked about and here's a list of some of the different
certifications that we have an AWS and this is a growing list but understand
how these work with what the security and the accreditation and the compliance that you're trying to meet instead of
imposing in that and earlier in the slide deck there was a talk about a I think it's uptime and
it is a great certification for data centers for AWS it doesn't really work
for how our model works so asking us to meet a data center security model that doesn't work for cloud doesn't make a
whole lot of sense so putting that in an RFP and make it at a requirement can be problematic
finally terms and conditions understanding terms and conditions and
how the legal approach works is a critical step in this bringing hardware
terms and conditions or software terms and conditions sort of traditional terms and conditions into a procurement or a
framework approach typically inhibits the use of the cloud and typically can be very difficult to me this is where I
love to hide try and I know one of our lawyers is in the room is try to have legal talk ahead of time well ahead of
time to have an understanding because I've learned that when people have an understanding of why legal is a little
bit different then an interesting conversation can happen so so typically you have to think about this as a set of
commercial terms a commercial set of services and terms and conditions need to go with that so imposing traditional
one-time terms and conditions can be difficult understand those commercial terms as you go forward so finally once
this talk about Columbia a little bit we do do sell cloud to the government in
